title: Bush Heritage R Workshops
text:
Hello!
We’re very much looking forward to our 3 days of R’ing with you (July 23rd - 25th).
In preparation, please install R and RStudio. See Section 0.1.3 for instructions.
Once you have RStudio up and running, please install the following R packages. You can just copy and paste the code below into the console of RStudio and hit enter to install.

Day 1 - Data wrangling and visualisation in R

install.packages(c("tidyverse", "here", "lubridate", "lme4", "ggplot2", "patchwork"))



Day 2 & 3 - Statistical Modelling in R

install.packages(c('ggplot2', 'patchwork', 'DHARMa', 'MASS', 'Hmsc', 'sf', 'terra', 'tidyr', 'vegan', 'dplyr', 'ggcorrplot', 'fields'))


remotes::install_version("tmap", "3.3-4")

You’re also welcome to peruse the course notes linked to in the tabs above, but note that these are subject to change up until day of the course.
Cheers,
Christina, Caitie and Jackson


Installing R and RStudio

Windows

Download R from the CRAN website.
Run the .exe file that was just downloaded
Go to the RStudio download page
Under All Installers, download the RStudio Installer for Windows.
Double click the file to install it
Once it’s installed, open RStudio to make sure it works and you don’t get any error messages.



MacOS

Download R from the CRAN website.
Select the .pkg file for the latest R version
Double click on the downloaded file to install R
It is also a good idea to install XQuartz (needed by some packages)
Go to the RStudio download page
Under All Installers, download the RStudio Installer for MacOS.
Double click the file to install RStudio
Once it’s installed, open RStudio to make sure it works and you don’t get any error messages.



Linux

Follow the instructions for your distribution from CRAN, they provide information to get the most recent version of R for common distributions. For most distributions, you could use your package manager (e.g., for Debian/Ubuntu run sudo apt-get install r-base, and for Fedora sudo yum install R), but we don’t recommend this approach as the versions provided by this are usually out of date. In any case, make sure you have at least R 3.3.1.
Go to the RStudio download page
Under All Installers, select the version that matches your distribution and install it with your preferred method (e.g., with Debian/Ubuntu sudo dpkg -i rstudio-YYYY.MM.X-ZZZ-amd64.deb at the terminal).
Once it’s installed, open RStudio to make sure it works and you don’t get any error messages.




Updating R and RStudio
If you already have R and RStudio installed, first check if your R version is up to date:

When you open RStudio your R version will be printed in the console on the bottom left. Alternatively, you can type sessionInfo() into the console. If your R version is 4.0.0 or later, you don’t need to update R for this lesson. If your version of R is older than that, download and install the latest version of R from the R project website for Windows, for MacOS, or for Linux
It is not necessary to remove old versions of R from your system, but if you wish to do so you can check How do I uninstall R?
Note: The changes introduced by new R versions are usually backwards-compatible. That is, your old code should still work after updating your R version. However, if breaking changes happen, it is useful to know that you can have multiple versions of R installed in parallel and that you can switch between them in RStudio by going to Tools > Global Options > General > Basic.
After installing a new version of R, you will have to reinstall all your packages with the new version. For Windows, there is a package called installr that can help you with upgrading your R version and migrate your package library.

To update RStudio to the latest version, open RStudio and click on Help > Check for Updates. If a new version is available follow the instruction on screen. By default, RStudio will also automatically notify you of new versions every once in a while.

title: About Us
text:
Dr Christina Buelow
Dr Christina Buelow is a quantitative ecologist who loves data and models. She got her start as a field ecologist, but these days she spends most of her time behind a computer developing models and tools to solve challenging problems related to conservation and sustainable use of Earth’s ecosystems. Currently, she is working closely with international NGOs to inform climate-smart conservation of coastal ecosystems.


Dr Caite Kuempel
Dr Caitie Kuempel is a marine ecologist turned quantitative modeler. She leads the Conservation Action Team at Griffith University. Her research synthesises new and existing data to quantify the what and where of human impacts on biodiversity from local to global scales and the actions that can be taken to reduce these threats. Her work largely falls within four main themes: 1) cumulative impacts of human activities, 2) spatial conservation planning, 3) land-sea interactions and 4) achieving conservation targets. This work can be used to quantify patterns between different locations, assess trade-offs between management actions, and inform conservation and sustainable development decisions.


Dr Jackson Stockbridge
Dr Jackson Stockbridge is a quantitative marine ecologist working on a marine spatial planning framework to inform ocean management. This involves using spatial data to map ocean uses, and the cumulative impact of multiple stressors on marine ecosystems. Having grown up in the UK, he moved to Adelaide South Australia to undertake a bachelor’s degree in marine biology. He then went on to complete his PhD, where he evaluated common assumptions of methods to calculate the impact of multiple stressors on marine environments. Her is currently a post-doctoral fellow as part of the Blue Economy Cooperative Research Centre Marine Spatial Planning project where he is constructing frameworks and analysis to better integrate cumulative impacts in offshore Blue Economy planning and development.
